discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Because it says Overlay segments, it's A VNI. Otherwise it could be B. VLAN ID.

Selected Answer: A
Reference: https://nuwan.vip/nsx-t-logical-switching/

Selected Answer: A
According to the VMware NSX Documentation, a segment is mapped to a unique Geneve segment that is distributed across the ESXi hosts in a transport zone. The Geneve segment uses a virtual network identifier (VNI) as an overlay network identifier. The VNI ID can be used to identify overlay segments in an NSX environment if troubleshooting is required.

questions.question_text: What can the administrator use to identify overlay segments in an NSX environment if troubleshooting is required?

discussion.content: TraceFlow only check route path. I think that the correct answer AD
Why not the Flow Monitoring option? It's better than TraceFlow, isn't it? And then the answer would be: AD

Selected Answer: AC
Saw in the ICM 4.0 : 
NSX 4.0.1 supports the following features with DPUs: 
• L2 and L3 overlay networking 
• L2 VLAN networking 
• Observability features such as packet capture, IPFIX, TraceFlow, and port mirroring 
• East-west security features such as DFW, IDS, and IPS (Tech Preview)

Selected Answer: AC

choices.C: From the NSX UI the URI in the address bar must have "local=false" part of it.
choices.B: From VMware Identity Manager the status of the remote access application must be green.
choices.D: From the NSX CLI the status of the VMware Identity Manager Integration must be "Configured".
choices.A: From the NSX UI the status of the VMware Identity Manager Integration must be "Enabled".

VMware Identity Manager Connection status is Up and VMware Identity Manager Integration is Enabled with green color.
